intro: Sclerochloa borreri, commonly known as the desert needlegrass, is a perennial grass native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its wiry, needle-like leaves and tufted growth habit, which help it conserve water in harsh environments. The plant produces small, spikelet-based inflorescences that are typically green or brown in color. Sclerochloa borreri is well adapted to drought conditions, with deep root systems that allow it to access moisture from deeper soil layers. It plays an important ecological role in stabilizing sandy soils and providing forage for wildlife.
